docs.title: Welcome to VectorPro's Tutorial WebSite
docs.text: Source code is here.

docs.title: vector_pro
docs.text:
C++
template < class value_type > class vector_pro; // generic template

Same as std::vectors, vector_pros are sequence containers representing arrays that can change in size.

Vector_pros use contiguous storage locations for their elements. Unlike arrays, their size can change dynamically, with their storage being handled automatically by the container.

Don't have much differences with vectors, vector_pros use a dynamically allocated array to store their elements. Instead of reallocating each time an element is added to the container, vector_pro containers may allocate some extra storage to accommodate for possible growth, and thus the container may have an actual capacity greater than the storage strictly needed to contain its elements. However we currently not support libraries to implement different strategies for memory growth, we just simply double the capacity at logarithmically growing intervals of size so that the insertion of individual elements at the end of the vector can be provided with amortized constant time complexity.

Most of the above text are just copied from std::vector .

docs.title: Template parameters
docs.text:
C++
template <class value_type>

Only if value_type is guaranteed to not throw while moving, implementations can optimize to move elements instead of copying them during reallocations.

docs.title: Member types and Macros
docs.text: member type definition notes iterator_pro a random access iterator to value_type convertible to const_iterator_pro, more info in iterator_pro const_iterator_pro a random access iterator to const value_type more info in iterator_pro vector_pro_exception exception inherits from std::exception, more info in exception_pro size_type an unsigned integral type in a 64-bit system will be int64_t; 32-bit system will be int32_t; the others will just be long int. VECTOR_PRO_DEFAULT_SIZE initial size of a vector default will be 64, self-defined is available

docs.title: See Also
docs.text:
To learn more about std::vector .

To visit out gihub page.

docs.title: vector_pro::assign
Assign vector content
docs.text:
Assigns new contents to the container, replacing its current contents, and modifying its size accordingly.

  1. range version the new contents are elements constructed from each of the elements in the range [from, exclude_to) , in the same order.

  2. fill version the new contents are num elements, each initialized to a copy of val.

  3. initializer list versionthe new contents are copies of the values passed as initializer list, in the same order.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. from, exclude_toInput iterators to the initial and final positions in a sequence. The range used is [from, exclude_to), which includes all the elements between from and exclude_to , including the element pointed by from but not the element pointed by exclude_to.
  2. numNew size for the container.
  3. valValue to fill the container with.
  4. anotherAn std::inializer_list object of the same type.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear on initial and final sizes (destructions, constructions).

docs.title: vector_pro::at
docs.text:
C++
value_type& at(const size_type position);

docs.title: Access element
docs.text:
Returns a reference to the element at position in the vector.

The function automatically checks whether n is within the bounds of valid elements in the vector, throwing an out_of_range exception if it is not.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. positionPosition of an element in the container.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: The reference of the element at the specified position in the container.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::back
docs.text:
C++
value_type& back();

docs.title: Access element
docs.text:
Returns a reference to the last element in the vector.

Calling this function on an empty will get an exception .

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A reference to the last element in the vector.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::begin
docs.text:
C++
iterator_pro begin() noexcept;

docs.title: Return iterator to beginning
docs.text:
Returns an iterator pointing to the first element in the vector.

If the container is empty, the returned iterator value shall not be dereferenced.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: An iterator to the beginning of the sequence container.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::capacity
docs.text:
C++
size_type capacity() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return size of allocated storage capacity
docs.text:
Returns the size of the storage space currently allocated for the vector, expressed in terms of elements.

Notice that this capacity does not suppose a limit on the size of the vector. The theoretical limit on the size of a vector is given by member max_size.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: The size of the currently allocated storage capacity in the vector, measured in terms of the number elements it can hold.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::cbegin
docs.text:
C++
const_iterator_pro<value_type> cbegin() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return const_iterator to beginning
docs.text:
Returns a const_iterator_pro pointing to the first element in the container.

Just like the const_iterator , which is an iterator that points to const content. This iterator can be increased and decreased (unless it is itself also const), just like the iterator_pro returned by vector_pro::begin, but it cannot be used to modify the contents it points to, even if the vector object is not itself const.

If the container is empty, the returned iterator value shall not be dereferenced.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A const_iterator to the beginning of the sequence.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::cend
docs.text:
C++
const_iterator_pro<value_type> cend() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return const_iterator to beginning
docs.text:
Returns a const_iterator_pro pointing to the past-the-end in the container.

Just like the const_iterator , which is an iterator that points to const content. This iterator can be increased and decreased (unless it is itself also const), just like the iterator_pro returned by vector_pro::end, but it cannot be used to modify the contents it points to, even if the vector object is not itself const.

If the container is empty, this function returns the same as vector_pro::cbegin.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A const_iterator to the end of the sequence.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::clear
docs.text:
C++
void clear() noexcept;

docs.title: Return const_iterator to beginning
docs.text: Removes all elements from the vector (after destroyed), leaving the container with a size of 0.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear in size (destructions).

docs.title: vector_pro::vector_pro
Construct vector
docs.text:
Constructs a vector_pro, initializing its contents depending on the constructor version used:

  1. default constructor Constructs an container, with VECTOR_PRO_DEFAULT_SIZE.

  2. fill constructor Constructs a container with len elements. Each element is a copy of val (if provided).

  3. range constructor Constructs a container with as many elements as the range [from, exclude_to) and in the same order.

  4. copy constructor Constructs a container with a copy of each of the elements in another, in the same order.

  5. move constructor Constructs a container by moving each of the elements in another, in the same order.

  6. std::vector constructorConstructs a container with a copy of each of the elements in another, in the same order.

  7. initializer list constructor Constructs a container with a copy of each of the elements in another, in the same order.

  8. traditional array constructorConstructs a container with a copy of each of the elements in another, in the same order.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. lenInitial container size.
  2. valValue to fill the container with.
  3. anotherAnother container object of the same type.Can be a std::vector , std::inializer_list or just another vector_pro.
  4. from, exclude_toIterators to the initial and final positions in a range. The range used is [from, exclude_to), which includes all the elements between from and exclude_to , including the element pointed by from but not the element pointed by exclude_to.
  5. arrTraditional array.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant for the default constructor (1), and for the move constructors (3) . For all other cases, linear in the resulting container size.

docs.title: vector_pro::data
docs.text:
C++
value_type *data() always_except;

docs.title: Do nothing
docs.text: Due to the data structure used in vector_pro, vector_pro doesn't support this operation yet. (Maybe in the near future ?)

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: Throw an exception.

docs.title: Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::~vector_pro
docs.text:
C++
~vector_pro();

docs.title: Destruct vector
docs.text: Destroys the container object, after destructs each element by calling ~value_type() (if has).

docs.title: Complexity
docs.text: Linear in size (destructors).

docs.title: vector_pro::emplace
Construct and insert element
docs.text:
The container is extended by inserting a new element val at position.

This effectively increases the container size by one.

An automatic reallocation of the allocated storage space happens if -and only if- the new vector size surpasses the current vector capacity.

A similar member function exists, insert, which either copies or moves existing objects into the container.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. positionPosition in the container where the new element is inserted.Can be a size_type or an (const_)iterator_pro.
  2. valValue of the new element.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: Type will be same as the position. (size_type / iterator_pro)

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear on the number of elements after position (moving).

docs.title: vector_pro::emplace
docs.text:
C++
size_type emplace_back(const value_type& val);

docs.title: Construct and insert element at the end
docs.text:
Inserts a new element at the end of the vector, right after its current last element.

A similar member function exists, push_back, which either copies or moves an existing object into the container.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. valValue of the new element.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant (amortized time, reallocation may happen).

docs.title: vector_pro::empty
docs.text:
C++
bool empty() const noexcept;

docs.title: Test whether vector is empty
docs.text: Returns whether the vector is empty (i.e. whether its size is 0).

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: true if the container size is 0, false otherwise.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::end
docs.text:
C++
iterator_pro end() noexcept;

docs.title: Return iterator to beginning
docs.text:
Returns an iterator pointing to the past-the-end element in the vector.

If the container is empty, the returned iterator value shall not be dereferenced.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: An iterator to the element past the end of the sequence.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::erase
Erase elements
docs.text:
Removes from the vector either a single element (position) or a range of elements ([from, exclude_to)).

This effectively reduces the container size by the number of elements removed, which are destroyed.

Please note that if the variables position, from, or exclude_to exceed the bounds of the vector, this function will throw an exception. You will also get one when from is gt exclude_to .

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. positionPosition in the container where the target element is.Can be a size_type or an (const_)iterator_pro.
  2. from , exclude_toThe range of elements we are going to erase.Can be size_types or (const_)iterator_pros.the range includes all the elements between from and exclude_to, including the element pointed by from but not the one pointed by exclude_to.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text:
Type will be same as the position. (size_type / iterator_pro)

The return value will point to the new location of the element that followed the last element erased by the function call.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear on the number of elements erased (destructions) plus the number of elements after the last element deleted (moving).

docs.title: vector_pro::front
docs.text:
C++
value_type& front();

docs.title: Access element
docs.text:
Returns a reference to the first element in the vector.

Calling this function on an empty will get an exception .

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A reference to the first element in the vector.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::insert
Insert elements
docs.text:
The vector is extended by inserting new elements before the element at the specified position, effectively increasing the container size by the number of elements inserted.

This causes an automatic reallocation of the allocated storage space if -and only if- the new vector size surpasses the current vector capacity.

Because vectors use an array as their underlying storage, inserting elements in positions other than the vector end causes the container to relocate all the elements that were after position to their new positions. This is generally an inefficient operation compared to the one performed for the same operation by other kinds of sequence containers (such as list or forward_list).

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. positionPosition in the container where the new elements are inserted.Can be a size_type or an (const_)iterator_pro.
  2. valValue to be copied to the inserted elements.
  3. numNumber of elements to insert. Each element is initialized to a copy of val.
  4. from , exclude_toThe range of elements we are going to insert.Can be size_types or (const_)iterator_pros.the range includes all the elements between from and exclude_to, including the element pointed by from but not the one pointed by exclude_to.
  5. liAn initializer_list object. Copies of these elements are inserted at position (in the same order).

docs.title: Return value
docs.text:
Type will be same as the position. (size_type / iterator_pro)

The return value will point to the first of the newly inserted elements.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear on the number of elements inserted (copy/move construction) plus the number of elements after position (moving).

docs.title: vector_pro::max_size
docs.text:
C++
size_t max_size() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return maximum size
docs.text: Returns the maximum number of elements that the vector can hold.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: The maximum number of elements a vector container can hold as content.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::operator=
Assign content
docs.text:
Assigns new contents to the container, replacing its current contents, and modifying its size accordingly.

  1. copy assignmentCopies all the elements from another into the container.
  2. move assignmentMoves all the elements from another into the container.
  3. std::vector assignmentCopies all the elements from another into the container.
  4. initializer list assignmentCopies all the elements from another into the container.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. anotherCan be a std::vector , std::inializer_list or just another vector_pro.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: *this .

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Linear in size.

docs.title: vector_pro::operator[ ]
docs.text:
C++
value_type& operator[](size_type position);

docs.title: Access element
docs.text:
Returns a reference to the element at position in the vector container.

The function automatically checks whether position is within the bounds of valid elements in the vector, throwing an out_of_range exception if it is not. ( std::vector doesn't )

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. positionPosition of an element in the container.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: The reference of the element at the specified position in the container.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::pop_back
docs.text:
C++
void pop_back();

docs.title: Delete last element
docs.text:
Removes the last element in the vector, effectively reducing the container size by one.

This destroys the removed element.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::push_back
docs.text:
C++
void push_back(const value_type& val);

docs.title: Add element at the end
docs.text:
Adds a new element at the end of the vector, after its current last element. The content of val is copied to the new element.

This effectively increases the container size by one, which causes an automatic reallocation of the allocated storage space if -and only if- the new vector size surpasses the current vector capacity.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. valValue to be copied to the new element.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant (amortized time, reallocation may happen).

docs.title: vector_pro::rbegin
docs.text:
C++
iterator_pro<value_type> rbegin() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return iterator to reverse beginning
docs.text: Returns a iterator_pro pointing to the last element in the container and grows in a reverse way.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A reverse_iterator to the reverse beginning of the sequence.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::rend
docs.text:
C++
iterator_pro<value_type> rend() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return iterator to reverse beginning
docs.text: Returns a iterator_pro pointing to the first element in the container and grows in a reverse way.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: A reverse_iterator to the reverse end of the sequence.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::reserve
docs.text:
C++
void reserve(const size_type re_size);

docs.title: Request a change in capacity
docs.text:
Requests that the vector capacity be at least enough to contain re_size elements.

If n is greater than the current vector capacity, the function causes the container to reallocate its storage increasing its capacity to re_size (or greater).

In all other cases, the function call does not cause a reallocation and the vector capacity is not affected.

This function has no effect on the vector size and cannot alter its elements.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. re_sizeMinimum capacity for the vector.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: If a reallocation happens, linear in vector size at most.

docs.title: vector_pro::resize
Change size
docs.text:
Resizes the container so that it contains re_size elements.

If re_size is smaller than the current container size, the content is reduced to its first re_size elements, removing those beyond (and destroying them).

Different from std::vector , the capacity will shrink to re_size .

If re_size is greater than the current container size, the content is expanded by inserting at the end as many elements as needed to reach a size of re_size. If val is specified, the new elements are initialized as copies of val .

Different from std::vector , if val is not specified, vector_pro will do nothing.

If re_size is also greater than the current container capacity, an automatic reallocation of the allocated storage space takes place.

Notice that this function changes the actual content of the container by inserting or erasing elements from it.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. re_sizeNew container size, expressed in number of elements.
  2. valObject whose content is copied to the added elements in case that n is greater than the current container size.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text:
Linear on the number of elements inserted/erased (constructions/destructions).

If a reallocation happens, the reallocation is itself up to linear in the entire vector size.

docs.title: vector_pro::shrink_to_fit
docs.text:
C++
void shrink_to_fit();

docs.title: Shrink to fit
docs.text: Requests the container to reduce its capacity to fit its size.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: At most, linear in container size.

docs.title: vector_pro::size
docs.text:
C++
size_type size() const noexcept;

docs.title: Return size
docs.text:
Returns the number of elements in the vector.

This is the number of actual objects held in the vector, which is not necessarily equal to its storage capacity.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: none

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: The number of elements in the container.

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::swap
Swap content
docs.text:
Different from std::vector , the vector_pro::swap has two using ways.

  1. Swap contents between two index ( 1. 2. ): After calling this function, the contents at the two indexes will be moved to another index.
  2. Swap containers ( 3. ): After the call to this member function, the elements in this container are those which were in another before the call, and the elements of another are those which were in this. All iterators, references and pointers remain valid for the swapped objects.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
1. idx1 , idx2Target index. (can be in different container but should have the same type)
  2. anotherAnother vector container of the same type

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant.

docs.title: vector_pro::push
docs.text:
C++
void push(const value_type& val);

docs.title: Add element at the end
docs.text:
Adds a new element at the end of the vector, after its current last element. The content of val is copied to the new element.

This effectively increases the container size by one, which causes an automatic reallocation of the allocated storage space if -and only if- the new vector size surpasses the current vector capacity.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: 1. valValue to be copied to the new element.

docs.title: Return value
docs.text: none

docs.title: Example
Complexity
docs.text: Constant (amortized time, reallocation may happen).
